The reason why people may confuse "bar" and "far" it's because both consonants are plosives but there are slight differences in the way of articulation that let you know by visuals which one is it, and in the second video the pronunciation of "bar" is "var". the "v" is the pair of the "f", both are labiodental plosives while "b" is a bilabial plosive.

Hello, a student of music here, trained to hear voices within multi-part harmonic progressions/music pieces. There is really no illusion here, both answers are correct because it is the question that is asked very wrongly. The question is asking whether the note moved from high to low or from low to high, which creates a presumption that there is only one note that is moving. But if you listen carefully, maybe you could make out that two notes are played simultaneously each time. The intervals are both octaves (latter one is double octave), and they move in contrary motion to each other by the same interval (half of an octave), so it can be potentially difficult for an average individual to hear. If you have a piano or keyboard, or you could perhaps make use of some digital piano, play the notes C3 and C4 at the same time, then F#2 and F#4 at the same time. Sounds the same as the illusion audio, right? Because that is what is played. The C3 voice goes down to F#2, and C4 voice goes up to F#4. Thus, depending on the voice you are referring to, both answers can be correct.

I just took a Master's level class on perception, and we talked about the McGurk effect. They probably could have explained it better (based on the comments I just read) so here is what it is.
The audio of him speaking is the same. The reason why it sounds different is because of your perception of his lips. Yes. In the first part his lips look like they are saying bar. And yes. In the second part his lips look like they are saying far. However, try listening to the "far" part with your eyes closed. You can clearly tell that he is saying "bar". It is the perception of his lips saying "far" that is what makes it seem like he's saying "far".
Here's Wikipedia if you really don't believe me.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/McGurk_effect

And also this rises genuine interest about how our minds work, because logically I know that we are just mammals not so different from any other mammal ( this is when I tell my inner ego to STFU, when thinking logically ) And I understand that we are a product of a long line of evolution that has some "glitches" it its software :D If I dare say so...

Years ago I was exposed to the so-called "van Noorden percept" as a volunteer in a psychological study. First I heard repeated groups of three separate tones, call them a b c. The first and third, a and c, were the same pitch, but the middle one, b, was higher.  Visually it would look like a series of triangles:   , ' ,   , ' ,   , ' ,   , ' , and so on. After a while of this I started hearing something very different, and I couldn't believe my ears, or that the same sounds were continuing to be played. Now it sounded like a tone of one identical pitch was being repeatedly played, without any of the previous ups or downs. It's as if my brain was no longer bothering to map a series of triangles (or peaks and valleys) but two flat lines:  ,   ,   ,   ,  and  '      '      '      '  alongside each other simultaneously, sounding like one.  This isn't an illusion exactly, but possibly a more efficient way of plotting sound events. Can one apply similar reasoning to the Shepard effect?

What the audio is...
Two sounds at once for the first one.
The first audio is 2 tracks...
One going high-low and another going low-high. Putting them together, doesn't really change it that much to your ears so it is really what your brain decides to hear but not what you decide to hear... it sounds weird but it's true. The second audio track is the same. Exactly. When you hear him say "What about this one?" Your brain expects something different... so as I said before, your brain decides what to hear, and your brain... hears the opposite as the first audio.

#1,#2,#3,#4 Lo-Hi and Hi-Lo at the same time, it's like the number tones of a telephone, 2 notes for the same number.
If you look at the numbers as a grid, one note goes from low to high in the horizontal line,  and the other note goes from low to high in the vertical line.

1 2 3
4 5 6
7 8 9
* 0 #


Number -> note1 - note2
1 -> 1 - 1
2 -> 1 - 2
3 -> 1 - 3
4 -> 2 - 1
5 -> 2 - 2
6 -> 2 - 3
7 -> 3 - 1
8 -> 3 - 2
9 -> 3 - 3
* -> 4 - 1
0 -> 4 - 2
# -> 4 - 3

Electronic producer here.

1- Heard "Par" all the time
2- Circle has flashed only once
3- All of them are Hi-Low's
4- The lot of sine waves are based on Fourier's Theory a.k.a the principle of Additive Synthesis.

Fourier has proved any sound could be broken into 5400 (or 5200, can't remember now) Sine Waves.
The harmonic keep "increasing" while the fundamental tone (or sub) keeps phasing away from the Harmonics. A phenomenom called "Harmonic Detuning", where harmonics are moved away from the fundamental. Except, that in this case, the harmonics are staying still, the fundamental tone is the one who's moving. Considering the laws of compression. If your sine amplitude for the fundamental is lower than the other harmonics, it's presence in the music will be lost, making your mind confused from all of the low amplitude modulation getting lost in the other harmonics.

Thanks for the video. It made me think a lot about my beloved Additive Synthesis, and after watching it twice, I could come with this conclusion. Keep up the good work!

I'm not entirely sure, but I think there are two different notes being played at the same time. It is ascending and descending simultaneously for all the answers- why?

Each of the examples of high lows have 2 voices going on simultaeneously=/ One in the higher range and one in the lower.

So each example there is one voice - ascending and the other voice is descending.
So the answer for all of them is ascending and descending at the same time, depending on which voice you hear

Most people here the higher register voice though but not the lower, so many get the similar answer

It's not an "illusion" if you're just lying about it. At 1:22 you are not playing "two tones" only. A "tone" is a single periodic frequency. There are multiple tones being played at the same time, then one of them switches up and one switches down. Anyone trained at harmony can instantly recognize the difference between a single tone (one frequency) and a harmony made of two different tones therefore asking the question whether it got "higher" or "lower" doesn't make any sense. This isn't an illusion at all, just a misleading question that confuses people who aren't trained musically.

Hi ASAPScience. I have a question about hearing. When we hear a sound, we know even without looking, which direction the sound is coming from. And more amazingly, we are able to clarify if that sound is just low volume coming from a short distance, or is low volume because it's coming from far away. An even more amazingly we sometimes can decide if the sound is coming from behind an obstacle, all without having a look at where it's coming from. How are we identifying these differences?

Tritone Paradox and Shepard's Tone Illusion is the same thing. Because on a pipe organ it's many octaves played in one note. But the brain listen to that tone that are most comfortable. So when you play a note, and then another lower tone, it may sound like it's a high tone because the brain choose one of those tones in different octaves. And Shepard's Tone Illusion has the same point, even though Shepard's tone illusion is more famous to just being an chromathic scale up or down. (Sorry for my bad english, I am from Sweden).

The "tritone paradox" would be a lot easier if it wasn't played on an organ effect, the sound of which consists of multiple pipes at different octaves. If it were played on an instrument that didn't have such a complex frequency spectrum (piano, trumpet, voice) it wouldn't be hard at all. It's less about the interval (tritone) and really about the timbre of the instrument. The fact that it's a tritone just makes it harder because it's the interval that evenly divides an octave.

'The Invisible Man' (1933) ran into the issue of the McGurk Effect when making the movie. Because the Invisible Man was, well, invisible, the audience couldn't visually see his lips moving. At the beginning of the video, with the"Bar Bar Bar".... if you closed your eyes and listened you would not hear the difference.... so it's your eyes you can't trust not your ears. There's about 1/2 millisecond between what you see and what your brain interprets so your brain is compensating for the lag. That's why you hear "Far Far Far" instead of "Bar Bar Bar" when you're watching the video.

About the tritone. Both are kind of correct, in a hammond or transitor organ you can adjust the harmonics in the notes, meaning you are able to assign the notes two sound their lower octave harmonic and the higher one. That means that if you play, in this case the tritone (e.g. F B), the F will have F3 and F4, and the B will have B3 and B4 as harmonics. 

Chances are you first emphasis the F3 and then the B3 (low to high), F4 and then B3 (high to low), F4 and then B3 (high to low too). 

Just try to sing to it and you'll be able to differentiate the diferent sounds that are played at the same time. If you want, later I can post some examples of this in audio.

Yes, I still believe my ears and there's no reason not to. The conditions under which the auditory illusions shown in the video occur are so specific and unusual that I doubt that they are easily encountered in the real world. For example, how many times am I going to encounter someone in the real world who moves their lips as if they were saying "far" but they utter "bar" instead? Or when would I encounter the Shepard Tone Illusion in the real world? Is this something that I am likely to encounter in my day-to-day activities: multiple sine waves played on top of one another raising in pitch while one quickly drops down an octave as the others continue rising? So, yes, I still believe my ears!

Quite interesting! I don't think the powers of audition are as cool as those of vision, but these were neat.

Obviously vision will have an impact on what you hear. That's why I try to make sure I enunciate properly (as posh as that may sound :P).
I don't really mix up consonant sounds. Spanish/English for example, the Spanish v and English b can sorta sound the same. It never confuses anyone because of the context, but the same principle applies. Two sounds can sound the same, so they might as well be the same sound; the experiment in the video is pretty much what happens whether the sound [clip] is the same or not.
I do mix up vowel sounds though. I can pronounce "bag" as either "beg" or a hybrid of the two "Ba-eg." I add more sounds and change the stress of the word or no real reason and I notice it but don't change it.

The second one was the least impressive, actually (edited post). The sound does not affect vision as much, perhaps because people rely more on vision than sounds in small environments (as opposed to a loud crash of rubble). It's kind of like a mouse click. You get two clicks (hold and release) but one input; it's not liked you pressed twice. It was essentially a signal sound. It might be different with other situations, but this one was kind of weak.

The third one was kinda weird. I don't know if this has to do with "left and right brain" mechanics but I kinda immediately picked up two different ways to hear it. I listened again to try and isolate the two sounds for each sound clip. Then it was explained that there were actually two frequencies so all was well.
If it makes any difference, the most powerful changes I heard my first time listening were:
1. High, Low
2. High, Low
3. Low, High
4. Low, High

The last one kinda threw me for a loop. I hear two frequencies increasing (low and high) and after a while you start to think and the chain is broken temporarily. I feel that there are multiple frequencies though, some of which don't increase (the lowest ones). It may be all in my head though, trying to find what isn't there.

ALSO has anyone ever listened to a song but sometimes it sounds slow and sometimes it sounds fast even though it's the same sound clip? Does that have to do with how awake and alert you are? I'm surprised it wasn't mentioned in the video. I was actually hoping that would be here.

I have a musical ability called Perfect Pitch which allows me to hear a pitch that comes from ANY sound, any instrument, and know what it is like A, A-flat, D-sharp, C-flat (which equals to B) and so on. ALSO, I know how high the frequencies of notes are. Middle C, just letting you know, is C4. Okay, so the first tri tone pitch was actually a combination of two notes. They sound a like because they're either an octave or two octaves apart. The first pair of TWO notes were (C3 and C5) to (F-sharp 3 and F-sharp 5) QUICK NOTE! If I just say the letter name without -sharp or -flat, it's natural. The LOWER octave notes are going DOWN, while the UPPER octave notes are going UP. To be exact, the lower octave notes went DOWN by 3 whole steps (C3 to F-sharp 3), and the upper octaves went UP by 3 whole steps. (C5 to F-sharp 5). Okay, so here's the others. (#2) (B-flat 3 and B-flat 4) to (E3 and E5) The LOWER octaves are going DOWN and the UPPER octaves are going UP. I HOPE THIS MAKES SENSE TO YOU!!!!!! XD (#3) (D3 and D5) to (G-sharp 3 and G-sharp 4) This time, the LOWER went UP while UPPER went DOWN. (#4) (F3 and F4) to (B2 and B4) LOWER went DOWN while UPPER went UP. For me, I TRUST MY EARS WHEN IT COMES TO PITCHES AND FREQUENCIES!!!!!)

What's really amazing is that the higher octave notes tends to sound LOUDER than the lower notes. In Orchestra, the Basses are the foundation of the orchestra. We feel the bass, but we don't really hear the notes. So, through that long and maybe confusing paragraph, by listening to the upper octaves, you might say (#1) went up, (#2) went up, (#3) went down, and (#4) went up. If you focus more on the lower octave notes, you could say that (#1) went down, (#2) went down, (#3) went up, and (#4) went down.

The last thing on the video with the red ball, going up, like I said, we tend to listen to the higher notes because they stand out compared to the lower frequency notes, even though they are the same NOTES, the FREQUENCIES are different. REALLY COOL ISN'T IT!!!!?????

It did not worked for me, I guess there are exceptions. Specially with the last one, I could hear they put the same tone at the beginning in the last ''pitch''.

I didn't trust my left ear to begin with. I deal with issues where my left ear doesn't fully hear things, and my brain kinda fills in the gap. This makes me hear people say my name when no one is there, frequently. And it doesn't always help me dictate whether or not sounds come directly from me, because the difference in what my ears hear make it sound like it's coming from a distance. So if I walk in grass that's covered in leaves, my brains thinks I'm hearing someone a small distance away walking in the leaves because it legit sounds like it's coming from a distance.

I should add I'm partially deaf in the ear, and I'm (obviously) am more susceptible to illusions, and this is just me speculating (but I've also spoken with a therapist about it, and he thinks so, too)

Without headphones:
1) Ascending
2) Descending
3) Ascending
4) I hear two notes playing at once for the second tone? The Descending tone sounds stronger, though.

With headphones:
1) The first note seems to have two tones playing overlayed with each other, however ascending-wise still sounds stronger.
2) I hear two tones for both. The first set sounds more closed (such as a second or a third) while the second sounds more open (like a fifth or an octave)
3) Again two tones for both. I hear ascending more than descending.
4) Very obvious that there are two tones on the second set of notes.

I feel that these tones are playing with the "overtone series". When a note is played, your ear "hears", or at least picks up on, several higher tones, whether you know it or not. It seems that these sounds are manipulated so that some of these tones higher on the overtone series are exaggerated, and the next tone (i'm guessing a tritone away from the "fundamental" tone of the first) has a different note in the overtone series that is exaggerated. Whether we hear the fundamental note or the exaggerated overtone probably has to do with what kind of music we are exposed to. Certain composers loved to mess with the overtone series, and if you are a brass player, the overtone series should be implanted in your brain and memorized by rote. Very interesting experiment that I will be sure to read up about when I'm not dead tired
